title: Paddy Power should have put a wager on its own merger with Betfair
text:

Wed, Aug 26, 2015, 10:53 BST - UK Markets close in 5 hrs 37 mins Paddy Power should have put a wager on its own merger with Betfair By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 9 minutes ago 93.00 +14.5000 
Betting firm joked on Twitter (Xetra: A1W6XZ - news ) last month that it was merging with Betfair to create a company called Betty Power. One month later it announced it was doing just that 
Bookmakers are supposed to be prescient but Paddy Power (LSE: PAP.L - news ) seems to have taken it to the next level when it joked last month about merging with rival Betfair; this morning the management team revealled the two companies were indeed in merger talks. 
Last month Paddy Power's social media team took to Twitter to poke fun at the frenzied pace of dealmaking within the gambling sector, which has seen rivals Ladbrokes (Amsterdam: LB6.AS - news ) and Gala Coral announced a £2.3bn deal and Bwin.party, an online gaming group, hold takover talks with both 888 and GVC. 
However, the Paddy Power tweet, sent on July 24, is now being made fun of on Twitter with users adopting the spoof hashtag #BettyPower 
The merger news prompted some online banter between the new partners. 
The Irish gambling company has built up a reputation for its outspoken and often controversial social media and marketing campaigns. 
In April, the Irish betting firm was forced to apologise for likening Newcastle United's record at Liverpool Football Club to police beatings of African-Americans. 
Last August, the firm sparked amusement when it posted a series of flirty text responses to a man called Steve who accidentlly texted the wrong number. 
As a warm-up to the Football World Cup, Paddy Power also sparked outrage when it leaked an image appearing to show that it had carved a message of support out of the Amazon rainforest. It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) later confirmed that it was a hoax and a move designed to urge people to save rainforest wildlife. 
In February this year the company continued to push boundaries with an advertising campaign that featured a team of players wearing Middle Eastern robes in an obvious jibe at the foreign owners of British football clubs. 
However, Paddy Power was engulfed in a storm over its marketing push in June which featured a picture of a lorry at Dover with the caption: "Immigrants, jump in the back! But only if you're good at sport." 
The group's "blind football" advert is one of the most complained about campaigns.
